results.title: White-throat
results.brief_description: A nature film without commentary photographed in Canada’s Algonquin Park. A white-throated sparrow is the central character, but other inhabitants are included: young wolves at play, other birds, shoals of fish in a lake, and a beaver at work.

results.title: Whistling Smith
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Barrie Howells, Michael Scott and Marrin Canell
results.brief_description: Sergeant Bernie “Whistling” Smith pounds the beat on Vancouver’s east side - the hang-out of petty criminals, down-and-outs, and a variety of unsavory characters. His policing is unorthodox. To many a drug user, petty thief, or young woman drawn into prostitution, he is more than the iron hand of the law, he is also counsellor and friend. Here is a revealing insight into one side of big-city life and a tough cop with a big heart.

results.title: Whistle for Willie
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios, Morton Schindel and Mal Wittman
results.brief_description: The story of a little boy trying to learn how to whistle for his dog the way the older boys do is told in lovely simple words and beautiful glowing pictures. The minimal animation adds beauty to Ezra Jack Keats’ cut-paper illustrations. Story teller: Jane Harvey. From the book written and illustrated by Ezra Jack Keates.

results.title: Whistle down the wind [study extract]
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Mary Hayley Bell, this extract is the story about a group of children living on a remote farm in the north of England who find a man whom the believe to be Christ. In reality he is a murderer on the run from justice. In the extract we see the children in their country environment and at their home situation. For the first time since “Christ” came to the barn, they talk with him. In the farmhouse, at tea, their father questions Kelly about talking to strange men, which she denies. After leaving the village shop with goods for the man, the three children meet a crowd of friends. The crowd eventually follows them to the farm gate and Kathy is persuaded to let them see “Jesus”.

results.title: Whisky galore!
results.creator_credit: Ealing Studios, Sir Michael Balcon and Alexander Mackendrick
results.brief_description: An hilarious, fast-paced comedy about a tiny and remote Hebridean island, Todday which is plunged into the depths of despair. Spirits are at zero for Todday is without whisky. Then a World War II ship founders on the rocks and the Scottish islanders guide the crew to safety. The ship’s captain and mate reveal that the cargo was 40,000 cases of whisky bound for America. Delayed for a day because of the Sabbath, the islanders eventually succeed in removing a considerable amount of the cargo and the dawn breaks with a rosy glow on a brighter, happier island, but the whisky does not last forever. Starring Basil Radford and Joan Greenwood. Co-starring James Robertson Justice, Gordon Jackson, Wylie Watson, Catherine Lacey and Jean Cadell. Based on the novel by Compton Mackenzie who has a small role as Captain Buncher. This film was released in the U.S. under the titles “Tight Little Island” and “Mad Little Island.”

results.title: While the city sleeps
results.creator_credit: RKO Radio Pictures, Burt Friedlob and Fritz Lang
results.brief_description: The editorship of a major city newspaper comes to rest upon the search for a psychopathic murderer (the “lipstick killer”). Although widely dismissed or neglected by critics, this is a film which Lang regarded as equal to his classic ‘M’. Thematically it bears comparison in the implication that socially acceptable levels of society are little different from the noir underworld. The murderer is more sympathetic than the newspaper people. There are also explicit parallels between the murderer and the ‘hero’ played by Dana Andrews, who at one stage uses his girlfriend as ‘bait’ for the killer. Stylistically this is Lang at his most lucidly refined. Cast includes Dana Andrews, George Sanders, Rhonda Fleming, George Sanders, Vincent Price and Ida Lupino. Based on the novel “The Bloody Spur” by Charles Einstein.

results.title: Which is my world?
results.brief_description: Shows how our demand for new things leads us to discard still usable items, how materials are consumed or permanently altered, and how the altered materials lie in mounds that scar our environment.

results.title: Which go together?: math readiness
results.brief_description: Uses sets of blocks of different colours and a story about a doll in order to illustrate the concept of set-building. Suitable for children aged 3-5. No other credits available.

results.title: Which energy
results.brief_description: SUMMARY: Different present and future energy sources are outlined and evaluated. These include fossil fuels, nuclear fusion, fission, the breeder reactor, solar energy, wind, and ocean-thermal and geothermal power sources
